statement: As someone who values law and order but also believes deeply in fairness and personal responsibility, I think policing strategies should focus on better training, clear rules of engagement, and real accountability when officers cross the line. We need to support good officers with the tools, staffing, and community relationships they need to do their jobs safely, while using body cameras, data on stops and use of force, and consistent discipline to address any bias. That way we can keep our neighborhoods safe, respect the rights and dignity of every person, and maintain trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve.

statement: La policía tiene un trabajo difícil y peligroso, y yo creo que hay que apoyarla con buen entrenamiento, salarios dignos y respeto, no debilitándola con ataques constantes. Dicho eso, también es importante que se corrijan los abusos: cámaras corporales obligatorias, disciplina real para los que se exceden y reglas claras sobre el uso de la fuerza. Las quejas por discriminación deben investigarse a fondo, pero sin convertir a todos los agentes en sospechosos por unos pocos. Si se combina firmeza contra el crimen con supervisión seria y transparente, se puede proteger a la comunidad sin perder el orden.

statement: As a nurse who sees firsthand how trauma and mistrust affect patients and families, I believe policing needs stronger de-escalation training, strict accountability for excessive force, and real community engagement—especially in communities of color—so people feel protected, not targeted. At the same time, officers deserve good training, mental health support, and clear policies so they can do their jobs safely and fairly. We should invest more in mental health services, education, and youth programs so police aren’t the default response to every social problem. Public safety is strongest when law enforcement, healthcare, schools, and families work together with transparency and respect.

statement: As a young Black man who’s seen how easily people who look like me can be treated as a threat, I think policing has to be grounded in accountability, de-escalation, and real community partnership. We need strict, enforced standards on use of force, mandatory body cameras, and independent investigations of misconduct, along with better training that focuses on implicit bias and mental health crises. At the same time, officers should be supported in doing their jobs safely, but that support has to come with transparency and consequences when they abuse their power. Public safety and civil rights aren’t opposites—if police earn trust by treating everyone fairly, it makes all of us safer.

statement: As a retired cop, I’ll tell you straight: we need solid training, clear rules, and real accountability to deal with bias and use-of-force, but not at the expense of letting the streets go soft. Officers should wear body cameras, follow strict de-escalation protocols, and be disciplined when they cross the line, but they also need the backing of their departments and the public to act decisively when there’s a real threat. We should use data to spot problem officers and patterns of bias, fix them early, and weed out those who don’t belong in the job. You can respect people’s rights and dignity without tying the hands of the men and women who keep order.

statement: Como alguien que valora el orden, la seguridad y el trabajo duro, creo que la policía es necesaria y merece respeto, pero también debe ser bien entrenada para reducir los prejuicios y el uso excesivo de la fuerza. Se necesitan mejores filtros al contratar, más capacitación en cómo tratar con respeto a todas las comunidades (incluyendo latinos e inmigrantes), y cámaras corporales obligatorias para que haya transparencia. Al mismo tiempo, las leyes deben respaldar a los buenos oficiales para que puedan hacer su trabajo sin miedo cuando realmente enfrentan criminales peligrosos. Como cristiano, pienso que la justicia debe ir junto con la misericordia: firmeza contra el delito, pero trato digno para todas las personas.

statement: As someone who values law and order and has seen a lot in my 86 years, I believe we must support our police while still expecting them to be properly trained and held to clear standards. There should be strong, consistent training on de-escalation and fairness so officers treat everyone with respect, but they also need the tools and backing to respond firmly when there is real danger. I think local communities, including seniors like me, should have regular, respectful dialogue with police so concerns about bias and force can be addressed before problems grow. This way we can preserve public safety without abandoning our moral responsibility to treat people justly.

statement: As someone who has spent a lifetime caring for people as a nurse and now volunteers in my community, I believe policing should focus on de-escalation, strong mental health partnerships, and real accountability when force is misused. We need rigorous bias training, body cameras, and independent oversight so that communities—especially people of color—can trust officers to protect them rather than fear them. At the same time, officers should be well-supported, well-trained, and held to clear standards, so they can keep everyone safe without resorting to unnecessary violence.

statement: I think police should have to follow really clear rules about when they can use force, and they should wear body cameras so everyone can see what actually happened. They should also get better training on handling tough situations without violence and on understanding people from different backgrounds. At the same time, we still need enough officers to keep neighborhoods safe, especially for kids and families, so it’s about making policing fairer and more respectful, not getting rid of it.
